thread.title: Competitors work up a sweat at New Zealand's largest outdoor CrossFit event
thread.title_full: Competitors work up a sweat at New Zealand's largest outdoor CrossFit event

title: Competitors work up a sweat at New Zealand's largest outdoor CrossFit event
text:
Competitors work up a sweat at New Zealand's largest outdoor CrossFit event Last updated 15:40, February 20 2017 Metcon Madness / Facebook 
Metcon Madness 2017, held at College Rifles Complex, is New Zealand's largest outdoor CrossFit competition. 
The humidity was sitting around 80 per cent, but at least the rain held off for New Zealand's largest outdoor CrossFit competition. 
Hosted by Remuera CrossFit and Genesis Fitness in Auckland on the weekend, Metcon Madness consisted of five workouts (called WODs in CrossFit speak) across the day, with teams of four (two men, two women) battling it out for first place in their division; Beginner, Scaled, Masters and RX (top athletes). 
This year's competition had more than doubled in size from the inaugural event in 2016, with nearly 500 athletes from all over New Zealand competing and an estimated crowd of up to 1000. Jillian O'Neill's team, Kaimai Valley Crossfit, placed 4th in the Masters division. READ MORE: 
The Kaimai Valley CrossFit Masters team - (L-R) Pat Latu, Shaun O'Neill, Jillian O'Neill, Sharon Bottcher. 
It's the first competition the team have entered together, and "by far the biggest" too. "This feels like probably three times as big as last year," she says. "It's a good example of how a good event will grow really quickly." O'Neill's team, "all over 44 years old", come from "a tiny town called Te Aroha" in the Waikato. "We've got a population of less than 4500 people, and we've only got 70 members, whereas the Auckland teams have hundreds, so for us to compete at this level - and really hold our own - is doing really well for a little country town." 
She got into CrossFit just two years ago, and loves the adrenalin, the feeling of personal strength and the community spirit it creates. Metcon Madness / Facebook 
Nearly 500 competitors from around the country descended on Auckland for New Zealand's largest outdoor CrossFit competition. 
"It's really empowering as a woman, to be strong, and although in the middle of a workout you're thinking, 'what the F am I doing? This is killing me,' at the end of it the adrenalin buzz kicks in and you can't wait to do it again. 
"But it's just that fact of being fit, knowing you can keep up with your kids, knowing you can lift your heavy suitcase and do all that stuff yourself, that's kind of what CrossFit was designed for, to have people fit for life. 
"And there's a real community spirit around CrossFit, you become mates. None of us knew each other before this - or maybe just to say hello to because we're a small town. " 
Robert Wade, 46, has come up from Kawerau in the Bay of Plenty to compete with his team K.Fit. 
He's been doing CrossFit for three years, after trying out a free class at a Mt Maunganui CrossFit gym on a mate's recommendation. 
He says his strength is probably in the more gymnastic elements. 
"I'm not as strong as some of these big tanks here," he jokes. 
"I'm slowly getting there but I do notice my healing time is a little bit longer than some of these younger guys - you don't heal as fast as the young fellas." 
Wade says as they train hard and "try to eat as clean as we can all the time", the only special training the team do in the lead-up to a competition is to focus on the workouts as they are released. 
"So handstand walking, sled-pulling and that sort of stuff, but nothing too far out of the normal training we do." 
"We like rolling with the younger guys though as it keeps us competitive, it's a healthy sort of competition between us." - Stuff
